user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtPrintx:
```c
void UtPrintx(const void *Memory, uint32 Length)
{
    uint32       i;
    uint32       j;
    const uint8 *Byte_ptr = Memory;
    char         OutputLine[80];
    char *       OutPtr;

    i = 0;
    while (i < Length)
    {
        snprintf(OutputLine, sizeof(OutputLine), "%16lx: ", (unsigned long)&Byte_ptr[i]);
        OutPtr = OutputLine;
        OutPtr += strlen(OutputLine);
        for (j = 0; j < 16 && i < Length; j++, i++)
        {
            sprintf(OutPtr, "%02X  ", Byte_ptr[i]);
            OutPtr += 3;
        }

        UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_INFO, OutputLine);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function UtPrintx:
size_t size
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
OutPtr += strlen(OutputLine);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: OutputLine is a local array of 80 bytes and was populated with snprintf(OutputLine, sizeof(OutputLine), ...), which guarantees NUL-termination when sizeof(OutputLine) > 0. Therefore strlen(OutputLine) will not access beyond the bounds of OutputLine. (Hypothetical violating scenario: if OutputLine were not NUL-terminated—e.g. size passed as 0 or prior writes omitted the terminator—then strlen could read past the buffer and violate Rule 21.17.)
